title: Extract quantities from specification text and callouts
description:
Extend extraction beyond schedules/tables to capture quantities from:
- Specification text (e.g., 'use 3/4" plywood throughout')
- Detail callouts (e.g., '(12) #4 rebar @ 12" o.c.')
- General notes sections
- Cut sheets
- Assembly details

Current limitation: Only extracts from structured tables/schedules, missing significant quantity data in unstructured text.

Approach:
- Use Claude/LLM to parse specification paragraphs
- Extract callout annotations from drawings
- Parse general notes for material requirements
- Identify patterns like '(qty) material @ spacing'
- Link extracted quantities to material database

title: design: Extract quantities from specification text and callouts
design:
Unstructured Text Quantity Extraction Design:

1. Text Extraction Types (src/types.ts):
   - TextQuantity: { material, quantity, unit, context, confidence, source }
   - CalloutAnnotation: { text, location, pageNumber, extractedQuantity }
   - QuantityPattern: { regex, parser, materialType }

2. LLM-Based Extraction Service (src/services/text-extraction-service.ts):
   - extractFromSpecText(text): uses Claude to parse specification paragraphs
   - extractFromCallouts(annotations): parses callout patterns
   - extractFromGeneralNotes(notes): extracts from notes sections
   - parseQuantityPattern(text): identifies '(qty) material @ spacing' patterns

3. Extraction Patterns:
   - Callout: '(12) #4 rebar @ 12" o.c.' → 12 #4 rebar, 12" spacing
   - Specification: 'use 3/4" plywood throughout' → 3/4" plywood, area-based
   - General: 'provide X material' → extract X and material
   - Assembly: detail-specific quantities

4. Integration:
   - Add text extraction to document processing pipeline
   - Run after OCR/vision extraction
   - Combine with schedule extraction
   - Link to material database
   - Store with confidence scores

5. Implementation:
   - Create text extraction service with LLM integration
   - Define quantity patterns and parsers
   - Add callout annotation extraction
   - Integrate with existing extraction pipeline
   - Store text-extracted quantities separately

title: Apply prehistoric/dinosaur theme to tools, skills, and agents
description:
Rename all tools, skills, and agents to follow Constructosaurus prehistoric theme.

**MCP Tools** (src/mcp/tools.ts):
- search_construction_docs → excavate
- ingest_document → fossilize
- analyze_drawing → carbon_date
- generate_supply_list → bone_count

**Skills** (.kiro/skills/):
- solid-principles.md → bedrock-principles.md
- domain-driven-design.md → territorial-design.md
- typescript-fp.md → fossil-patterns.md
- git-commit-message.md → sediment-layers.md
- error-recovery.md → extinction-recovery.md

**Agents** (.kiro/agents/):
- software-architect → paleontologist
- workProducer → excavator
- workConsumer → fossil-hunter

Update:
- All references in code
- Agent configurations
- Documentation
- Welcome messages
- Keyboard shortcuts (keep same keys, update descriptions)

title: Add material intelligence and equivalents system
description:
Implement material understanding and conversion logic:
- Material equivalents (PSL vs LVL vs solid lumber)
- Unit conversions (board feet ↔ linear feet ↔ pieces)
- Stock sizing (need 11'6", buy 12' stock)
- Supplier-specific sizing and availability
- Material substitution rules

Current limitation: Treats materials as strings, no understanding of relationships or conversions.

Approach:
- Create material taxonomy/ontology
- Define equivalence rules
- Implement unit conversion library
- Add stock sizing calculator
- Integrate supplier catalogs (optional)

acceptance_criteria: Documents material equivalence rules and unit conversion standards
notes: Material Equivalents: PSL/LVL/solid lumber, concrete grades, steel grades. Unit Conversions: board feet ↔ linear feet ↔ pieces. Stock Sizing: round up to standard lengths (8', 10', 12', 16', 20'). Supplier catalogs: optional integration.

title: design: Add material intelligence and equivalents system
design:
Material Intelligence and Equivalents Design:

1. Material Taxonomy (src/types.ts):
   - MaterialCategory: LUMBER, CONCRETE, STEEL, etc.
   - Material: { id, name, category, properties, equivalents[] }
   - MaterialEquivalence: { from, to, conversionFactor, conditions }
   - UnitConversion: { fromUnit, toUnit, conversionFactor }

2. Material Intelligence Service (src/services/material-intelligence.ts):
   - findEquivalents(material): returns equivalent materials
   - convertUnits(quantity, fromUnit, toUnit): unit conversion
   - calculateStockSize(needed, stockSizes[]): rounds to standard sizes
   - substituteM aterial(material, constraints): suggests substitutes

3. Material Database:
   - Taxonomy of construction materials
   - Equivalence rules (PSL ≈ LVL ≈ solid lumber with factors)
   - Unit conversion tables
   - Standard stock sizes by material type

4. Integration:
   - Extend material extraction to use taxonomy
   - Apply conversions during quantity calculation
   - Suggest equivalents in takeoff reports
   - Calculate stock quantities with waste factor

title: Calculate fasteners, adhesives, and finish materials
description:
Extend quantity calculations to include:
- Fasteners (nails, screws, bolts per connection type)
- Adhesives/sealants (linear feet of joints, coverage rates)
- Finish materials (paint, stain coverage by surface area)
- Temporary materials (formwork, shoring, scaffolding)

Current limitation: Only calculates primary structural materials, missing consumables and finishes.

Approach:
- Define fastener schedules by connection type
- Calculate joint lengths for sealants
- Compute surface areas for finishes
- Add temporary material estimating rules
- Apply industry standard ratios

title: investigation: current material calculation scope
acceptance_criteria: Documents what materials are currently calculated and calculation methods
notes:
Current Material Calculation Scope:

From src/extraction/ and src/processing/:
- Schedule extraction: pulls quantities from tables (structural members, dimensions)
- Dimension extraction: measurements and sizes
- Focus on primary structural materials (concrete, steel, lumber)
- NO calculation of fasteners, adhesives, finishes, or temporary materials

Gap: Missing consumables and finish materials that are critical for complete takeoff

title: investigation: fastener, adhesive, and finish calculation standards
acceptance_criteria: Documents industry standards for calculating consumables and finishes
notes:
Fastener, Adhesive, and Finish Calculation Standards:

Fasteners:
- Wood framing: 1-2 lbs nails per board foot
- Steel connections: bolt count by connection type (beam-column, brace, etc.)
- Drywall: 32 screws per 4x8 sheet

Adhesives/Sealants:
- Coverage: 30-50 linear feet per tube (1/4" bead)
- Joint types: expansion joints, window perimeters, panel joints

Finishes:
- Paint: 350-400 sq ft per gallon (2 coats)
- Stain: 200-300 sq ft per gallon
- Surface area calculation from dimensions

Temporary Materials:
- Formwork: 1.1x concrete surface area
- Scaffolding: by building height and perimeter
- Shoring: by floor load and span

title: design: Calculate fasteners, adhesives, and finish materials
design:
Fasteners, Adhesives, and Finish Materials Calculation Design:

1. New Material Types (src/types.ts):
   - Fastener: { type, size, quantity, connectionType }
   - Adhesive: { type, coverage, linearFeet, tubes }
   - Finish: { type, coverage, surfaceArea, gallons }
   - TemporaryMaterial: { type, quantity, duration }

2. Calculation Services (src/services/):
   - FastenerCalculator: calculates by connection type and material
   - AdhesiveCalculator: computes joint lengths and coverage
   - FinishCalculator: calculates surface areas and coverage
   - TemporaryMaterialCalculator: estimates formwork, scaffolding

3. Calculation Rules:
   - Fasteners: ratio-based (1-2 lbs/board foot) + connection schedules
   - Adhesives: joint length extraction + coverage rates (30-50 LF/tube)
   - Finishes: surface area from dimensions + coverage (350-400 sqft/gal)
   - Temporary: formwork 1.1x concrete area, scaffolding by height/perimeter

4. Integration:
   - Extend extraction pipeline to calculate derived materials
   - Link to primary materials (lumber → fasteners, walls → paint)
   - Store in separate LanceDB tables with references
   - Add to material takeoff reports

5. Implementation:
   - Add material types to src/types.ts
   - Create calculator services
   - Define calculation rules database
   - Integrate with extraction pipeline
   - Update storage schema

title: Implement cross-document correlation and conflict resolution
description:
Add intelligence to correlate and resolve conflicts across multiple PDFs:
- Track same material specified in multiple documents
- Detect conflicts (spec says X, drawing says Y)
- Handle addenda and revisions
- Track 'as-built' vs 'design' versions
- Maintain document hierarchy (addenda > spec > drawing)

Current limitation: Each document processed independently, no cross-referencing.

Approach:
- Create document relationship graph
- Track revision dates and superseded documents
- Implement conflict detection rules
- Provide conflict resolution UI/API
- Maintain audit trail of changes

title: investigation: construction document hierarchy and revision practices
acceptance_criteria: Documents industry practices for document hierarchy and revisions
notes: Document Hierarchy: Addenda > Specifications > Drawings > General Notes. Revision tracking: date-based, superseded documents. Conflict types: quantity mismatch, material specification difference, dimension conflict. Need audit trail.

title: design: Implement cross-document correlation and conflict resolution
design:
Cross-Document Correlation and Conflict Resolution Design:

1. Document Relationship Model (src/types.ts):
   - DocumentRelationship: { type: SUPERSEDES|REFERENCES|CONFLICTS, from, to, date }
   - DocumentVersion: { id, version, date, status: CURRENT|SUPERSEDED }
   - Conflict: { type, documents[], description, resolution?, priority }
   - DocumentHierarchy enum: ADDENDA, SPECIFICATION, DRAWING, GENERAL_NOTE

2. Correlation Service (src/services/correlation-service.ts):
   - trackMaterialAcrossDocuments(material): finds same material in multiple docs
   - detectConflicts(): identifies quantity/spec/dimension conflicts
   - resolveConflict(conflict, resolution): applies resolution with audit trail
   - getEffectiveValue(material, documents[]): applies hierarchy rules

3. Conflict Detection Rules:
   - Quantity mismatch: same material, different quantities
   - Specification difference: same item, different specs
   - Dimension conflict: same element, different dimensions
   - Superseded reference: using old document data

4. Resolution Strategy:
   - Apply document hierarchy (addenda > spec > drawing)
   - Track revision dates
   - Maintain audit trail of conflicts and resolutions
   - Flag unresolved conflicts for review

5. Integration:
   - Add document relationship tracking to storage
   - Run conflict detection after multi-document processing
   - Provide conflict resolution API
   - Generate conflict reports

title: Implement quantity validation and sanity checks
description:
Add validation to catch errors and unrealistic quantities:
- Sanity checks (10,000 cubic yards concrete for small house?)
- Verify against typical ratios (rebar:concrete, fasteners:lumber)
- Compare to similar projects database
- Cost estimation validation
- Flag outliers for review

Current limitation: No validation, accepts any calculated quantity without verification.

Approach:
- Define validation rules by material type
- Create typical ratio database
- Implement statistical outlier detection
- Add cost-based validation
- Provide validation report with warnings

title: planning: Implement quantity validation and sanity checks
investigation: current quantity calculation and data flow
acceptance_criteria: Documents how quantities are currently calculated and where validation should be added
notes:
Current Quantity Calculation:

From src/extraction/ and src/processing/:
- Schedule extraction pulls quantities from tables
- Dimension extraction gets measurements
- No validation layer currently exists
- Quantities stored directly to LanceDB

Validation insertion points:
- After schedule extraction (validate tabular quantities)
- After dimension calculation (validate computed values)
- Before storage (final validation gate)
- Query time (flag suspicious results)

Need validation service in src/services/

title: investigation: typical construction material ratios and validation rules
acceptance_criteria: Documents industry-standard ratios and validation rules for common materials
notes:
Typical Construction Material Ratios:

Validation rules to implement:
1. Concrete: 100-150 lbs rebar per cubic yard
2. Framing: 1-2 lbs fasteners per board foot lumber
3. Drywall: 1 lb joint compound per 8 sq ft
4. Area ratios: foundation 10-20% larger than building footprint
5. Cost checks: $X-Y per sq ft by building type

Sanity bounds:
- Concrete: 10-500 CY per 1000 sq ft building
- Lumber: 5-15 board feet per sq ft floor area
- Rebar: #3-#8 bars typical, spacing 6-24 inches

Statistical approach:
- Flag values >3 standard deviations from mean
- Compare to similar project database
- Ratio validation between related materials

title: design: Implement quantity validation and sanity checks
design:
Quantity Validation and Sanity Checks Design:

1. Validation Service (src/services/validation-service.ts):
   - ValidationRule interface: { type, min, max, ratio?, message }
   - ValidationResult: { valid, warnings[], errors[], confidence }
   - validate(material, quantity, context): ValidationResult

2. Validation Rules Database:
   - Material-specific bounds (concrete: 10-500 CY per 1000 sqft)
   - Ratio rules (rebar:concrete 100-150 lbs/CY)
   - Cost ranges by building type
   - Statistical thresholds (3 sigma outliers)

3. Integration Points:
   - After schedule extraction: validate tabular quantities
   - After dimension calculation: validate computed values
   - Before storage: final validation gate
   - Add validationStatus field to stored materials

4. Validation Report:
   - Warning level: suspicious but possible
   - Error level: likely incorrect
   - Provide context and suggested ranges
   - Link to similar projects for comparison

5. Implementation:
   - Create ValidationRule type in src/types.ts
   - Build validation service with rule engine
   - Add validation calls in extraction pipeline
   - Store validation results with materials
   - Create validation report generator

title: Add context tracking for phasing and location
description:
Track material context to enable phased and location-based takeoffs:
- Construction phasing (foundation → framing → finishes)
- Location tracking (floor, room, grid reference)
- Conditional items ('if soil bearing < 2000 psf, use...')
- Sequencing dependencies
- Area/zone-based grouping

Current limitation: All materials in flat list, no context about when/where used.

Approach:
- Extract phase information from documents
- Parse location references (grid lines, room numbers)
- Identify conditional specifications
- Create material-location-phase graph
- Generate phased material delivery schedules

title: investigation: current material extraction and data model
acceptance_criteria: Documents current material extraction code, data structures, and storage schema
notes:
Current Material Extraction:

Data Model (src/types.ts):
- ConstructionMetadata: project, discipline, drawingType, materials, components
- Schedule: type, headers, rows (tabular data)
- ScheduleEntry: mark, data (key-value), rowNumber
- Dimension: valueFeet, gridReference, locationDescription, orientation
- NO phase or location context currently tracked

Key directories:
- src/extraction/ - extraction logic
- src/processing/ - document processors
- src/storage/ - LanceDB storage
- src/classification/ - document classification

Current limitation: Materials stored in flat structures without phase/location/conditional context.

title: investigation: phase and location information in construction documents
acceptance_criteria: Documents how phase, location, and conditional info appears in specs and drawings
notes:
Phase and Location Patterns in Construction Documents:

Common patterns to extract:
1. Phasing: 'Phase 1', 'Stage A', 'Foundation work', 'Framing', 'Finishes'
2. Location: Grid references (A-1, B-3), Floor levels (1st Floor, Level 2), Room numbers (101, 202)
3. Conditionals: 'if soil bearing < X', 'where required', 'as specified'
4. Sequencing: 'after foundation', 'prior to framing', 'concurrent with'
5. Area/Zone: 'North wing', 'Building A', 'Zone 1'

Existing partial support:
- Dimension.gridReference - grid line references
- Dimension.locationDescription - text descriptions
- Schedule data may contain phase/location in columns

Need to add:
- Phase field to materials
- Location hierarchy (building > floor > room > grid)
- Conditional rules
- Sequencing dependencies

title: design: Add context tracking for phasing and location
design:
Phase and Location Context Tracking Design:

1. New TypeScript Interfaces (src/types.ts):
   - Phase enum: FOUNDATION, FRAMING, MEP, FINISHES, SITEWORK
   - Location: { building?, floor?, room?, gridRef?, zone? }
   - ConditionalRule: { condition: string, applies: boolean }
   - MaterialContext: { phase?, location?, conditionals?, sequencing? }
   - ContextualMaterial extends existing material types with context field

2. Extraction Approach:
   - Phase: keyword matching ('foundation', 'framing', 'finish')
   - Location: parse grid refs (A-1), room numbers (101), floor levels
   - Conditionals: extract 'if/when/where' clauses
   - Sequencing: parse 'after/before/concurrent' references
   - Leverage existing Dimension.gridReference and locationDescription

3. Storage Schema (LanceDB):
   - Add columns: phase, building, floor, room, gridRef, conditionals, sequencing
   - Maintain backward compatibility with existing stores

4. Integration:
   - Extend material extraction in src/extraction/
   - Update processors in src/processing/
   - Add context extraction service
   - Update storage layer to persist context

title: design: Create comprehensive project documentation structure
design:
Documentation Structure Plan:

1. Directory Structure:
   docs/
   ├── architecture/     # System design, patterns, decisions
   ├── api/             # API documentation
   ├── guides/          # User and developer guides
   └── examples/        # Code examples and tutorials

2. Files to Create/Update:
   - docs/architecture/overview.md - System architecture
   - docs/architecture/processing-pipeline.md - Document processing flow
   - docs/api/README.md - API reference
   - docs/guides/getting-started.md - Setup and first steps
   - docs/guides/developer-guide.md - Development workflow
   - docs/examples/ - Working code examples
   - README.md - Update with Constructosaurus branding
   - QUICKSTART.md - Streamline for new users

3. Content Organization:
   - Clear hierarchy from overview to details
   - Cross-references between related docs
   - Code examples with explanations
   - TSDoc comments in source code

4. Implementation Phases:
   - Phase 1: Core docs (README, architecture overview)
   - Phase 2: API documentation
   - Phase 3: User guides
   - Phase 4: Examples and tutorials
   - Phase 5: Integration and polish

title: design: Rename ClaudeHopper to Constructosaurus
design:
ClaudeHopper to Constructosaurus Rename Design:

1. Naming Convention:
   - Display name: Constructosaurus
   - Package name: constructosaurus
   - Technical references: constructosaurus (lowercase)

2. Files to Update:
   - package.json: name, description
   - README.md: all references
   - PHASE*.md: all documentation
   - IMPLEMENTATION.md, AUDIT.md, VERIFICATION.md
   - MCP_SETUP_INSTRUCTIONS.md
   - Source code comments
   - Any other markdown files

3. Find/Replace Patterns:
   - ClaudeHopper → Constructosaurus
   - claudehopper → constructosaurus
   - ClaudeHopper-refactored → Constructosaurus
   - claude-hopper → constructosaurus

4. Preservation:
   - Maintain git history
   - No functional code changes
   - Only naming/branding updates

5. Implementation:
   - Use find/replace across codebase
   - Update package.json
   - Update all documentation
   - Verify no broken references
   - Test that package still works
